document.title: Sports, exercise and health science guide

CC6985570504483099ABB4698EA70837.description:
Imagery is an experience that mimics real experience. It involves using a combination of
different sensory modalities in the absence of actual perception.

89C5B2BADA7841E1B71D1C555DC21606.description:
The goal-setting paradox explains that elite athletes often feel less satisfied when a higher
goal is achieved than an easier goal. This is thought to be the result of feelings of deflation after
success.

521833102D864E0EA86AEEF6C0B0B11B.description:
Goal setting directs attention to a specific task. It is regularly used to enhance motivation
in sport, exercise and health.

35169CA46A844D0A8277A759F49E40D6.description:
Many coping strategies have been shown to be effective for athletes, although the
effectiveness of each is specific to the individual and the situation.

CB9F2B26B078437E9A95A1E914F1789C.description: Stressors can be considered as either controllable or uncontrollable.

6073D9DF85374CB59E0B1AD6617901AF.description:
A stressor causes psychological strain. This can be positive, such as looking forward to an
opportunity, or negative, such as fearing an outcome.

F8E8A157FA6743E9902906C4A8FB6CBD.description:
When anxiety is low, individuals experience positive emotions, such as excitement, desire
and elation. High levels of anxiety induce negative emotions such as fear, worry and despondency.

CF40E760201E42A3A3F9A4CDD3EEA40F.description:
Arousal refers to the level of physical and psychological activation. This impacts on sport
performance in the way that individuals attempt to manage their levels of intensity.

68EAF6B534BF4170ABBD93D8BB386A82.description:
Motivational climate describes the psychological environment that the coach creates by
designing sessions that provide instructions and feedback, which will help to motivate the athletes
in training or competition.

FC62BBFB56DD4B5088395E8617040B4D.description:
Self-determination theory is a meta-theory comprising six mini-theories, each explaining a
facet of individual motivation.

19D85B29711843718A75B9D7808A0038.description:
Motivation can be placed along a continuum from amotivation to controlled motivation to
autonomous motivation.

7F4F2434DEE9426C91DB3863C3EC4E28.description:
Self-determination theory hypothesizes that humans strive to satisfy needs of autonomy,
competence and relatedness.

042CBD3497FA4EAC962C10F065FF07E7.description: High ego orientation can be problematic if task orientation is low.

DE0577A1E29C4B3896FC08D028360D27.description: Goal orientation theory assumes that individuals strive to feel successful

56A1AB3432CA48A98938FA4E2262690F.description:
Need achievement theory posits that personality and situational factors interact to
produce resultant factors, which create emotional factors, which drive behavioural factors.

4824CD4FAE8B4ED2AFC1B369768ECC58.description: The proficient execution of specific skills requires the correct attentional focus.

E86F766CA9274BA291CA8BF935A3F0EF.description:
Transfer of learning refers to the influence of previous experience performing a skill on the
learning of a new skill.

105C89F43C3E46F881620517916C01EB.description:
The psychological refractory period is the time in which response to a second stimulus is
significantly slowed because a first stimulus is still being processed.

2B95FEF2F50E4C4C9B3236303E88BC68.description:
Learning, including motor learning, is a relatively permanent change in behaviour brought
about by experience, whereas performance is a temporary occurrence, fluctuating over time.

39F4FC6564184DD8A315350E2422FF95.description:
Attribution theory illustrates how the locus of control and locus of stability can impact
subsequent confidence.

CFE456763E104E30BF80ECDD2E4B2E6D.description:
Mental toughness is positively associated with better health outcomes, including fewer
depressive symptoms, fewer burnout symptoms and improved sleep quality.

9C1A8478BF1D45BEBA285A88AD1A359A.description:
The theory of the “self-fulfilling prophecy” in sporting success suggests that a
sportsperson’s perceived self-confidence results in greater persistence and effort, leading to an
increased probability of eventual success.

440F3FC376974A3884629559020E1ED1.description:
Mental toughness is an aspect of personality that partly explains how individuals manage
challenging and pressurized situations.

0DE13D2925B94B9AABAAA51B77BBD369.description: Personality can change over a long period of time.

A9B449300E874C8FB109D92E0EF1EBB2.description: Social learning theory is a situational approach to understanding behaviour.

69B88DB1DC614CC4BA4793FE422B24AC.description:
Personality refers to individual differences in characteristic patterns of thinking, feeling
and behaving. Personality is typically understood to be an interaction between genetic traits and
the environment.

86F885EA2C2345ACBAA8F2BA5C8B4A0C.description:
Treatment of concussion varies based on the specifics of the injury. The pace of recovery is
not always linear.

7792BA9C44CD4E3FB8579387B38F1869.description:
The initial stages of injury treatment often involve mitigation of inflammation.
Serious injuries that involve complete tears or major fractures will sometimes require surgical
repair.
In the healing process, therapeutic modalities (some managed by para-professionals) are provided
to promote healing and a safe return to activity.

D09F5B20DC544366A327ADB72FC261FC.description:
Methods of lowering the risk of injury attempt to minimize the abnormal application of
forces and maximize the ability of the body to absorb any such application of force.

4D29040969654B68A12523B9B3D63AEB.description: Chronic or overuse injuries are often related to technique.

A1489818649C402FBEC78D0643D79720.description:
An acute trauma is caused by a sudden or excessive application of force, or by a force from
an unexpected direction. A cumulative trauma is caused by the repeated application of force.

C18A60112B264B8B877AC1F17DB2BEB6.description:
The complex interaction of internal and external risk factors can predispose and make an
individual susceptible to injury.

7590B8DDF7634FE2A89A07B18958F5F3.description: A phases-of-movement approach is used to break down and describe movements.

3DCE92873811422F9EECF7A5DD09874F.description:
The forces of buoyancy, lift and drag acting on a body as it moves through a fluid (air or
water) have a measurable effect on its path.
A projectile travelling through a fluid may be affected by Bernoulli’s principle, the angle of attack
and the Magnus effect.

01CB1C09871846DB8FF4CBE0D6F4FF9F.description:
Environmental conditions such as temperature, humidity, air pressure, wind, salinity of
water and altitude affect the external forces acting on an object

605579F0E96645469301F038137328E0.description: The path of a projectile through air is determined by different factors and forces.

8D9856F3855F49D1927645F8C4C154AD.description: Work results from the application of a force over a distance.

5106E50E1A5A4B1EB2429671921F13D3.description: The force of friction is determined by the coefficient of friction.

9DF64563E62A4E828E01FE0829284729.description: A collision results in a change in momentum in the colliding bodies.

A51DB67E0DC04F0DBE053C65E3F0FBCC.description: Linear and angular motion can be analysed using Newton's laws of motion.

18BB9FFD39EE4AD6BFAD833ED30D7668.description:
Three different classes of levers, both within and outside the human body, work to create
movements

683E69C956A9422EA0990BCA855A4556.description:
The sliding filament theory describes the interaction between myofilaments and the
molecules responsible for sarcomere or muscle contraction.

D197B3B9EC254650850FFBEEF6B947E9.description:
The body uses different types of muscular contractions to create movement and stability.
Each type of contraction has a different function.

CEFB668181AD42FEB53EB83BBB333296.description:
The structure of connective tissues and joints are related to their function in enabling
movement.

1E1E6D33AD114161BD0951F9BD27183C.description: Structure and function of connective tissues and joints

6C0A8F9A01204E54AE4DD744C2063D31.description:
Anthropometry, the measurement of body segments and proportions of the human body,
has applications in many areas of sport and health science.

A25A92B3AF8F4202A0E5AB3A66497011.description: Movements occur in one or more planes, and rotations occur along one or more axes.

85BE805CD0104C74BE567B52D15A385E.description:
The human skeleton is divided into an axial component and an appendicular component.
These have different primary functions.

490250139D0C44F0B8E6C03BF7D0079B.description:
Fatigue can originate at different levels of the motor or energy pathway, possibly
combining a variety of sources.

B925198807934704942EB621228D9DC3.description:
Prescribing exercise for health and sporting performance needs careful consideration and
planning.

600C8AECDB2E49AE8256B4CC6BA58682.description: An active lifestyle supports physical well-being.

5DEBAEBFB97E4C0E9C3DC7C6DDEB1439.description: Benefits to health of being active

73DAA1C1F8ED4E0C9AFBA20D29762E00.description:
The quality of training design and programme design are essential elements in developing
a safe and effective programme for improving health or performance.

56691EE271AF460A9E4331308407E33D.description:
Excess post-exercise oxygen consumption (EPOC) is required for the body to return to
homeostasis and is dependent on the oxygen deficit incurred during exercise. EPOC is typically
divided into two subsections: fast and slow.

6E9719FD2FC04ECBAE301F48CDE96B0A.description:
The lactate inflection point is the maximum intensity at which the body can metabolize
lactate at the same rate as its production.

021EBA6E47914DD697F76DFB6F4B8BA6.description:
Maximal oxygen consumption (VO2
 max) is influenced by an individual’s age, sex
differences, body composition, lifestyle factors and level of fitness.

5CE5DACC54304FF5A7FADC23B127C95C.description:
The body relies on the phosphagen, glycolytic and oxidative systems for energy
production to sustain life and physical activity.

CEF3C5E8D6F7439393C4408BDD137350.description: The gut microbiome influences the health and performance of an individual.

604A1B2B02284342B80430B0060277F1.description:
Micronutrients play highly specific roles in facilitating energy transfer and tissue
synthesis.

D992E5C1ECF146D281CB5CE24181A944.description:
Macronutrients (carbohydrates, proteins and lipids) provide sources of energy to maintain
bodily functions during growth, rest and physical activity.

38D8E393880B46C79514AF20588C0E04.description:
Water and electrolyte balance is necessary for effective functioning of the body and is
influenced by the environment.

068D88DB421C4D259068E545BF6EE2F3.description:
The respiratory system enables the exchange of gases between the external environment
and the body, to facilitate cellular respiration.

B49E02DB94474500AFA074B00E7165DF.description:
The cardiovascular system transports nutrients, hormones, gases, heat and waste to
perform necessary bodily functions.

EC8E4FB5E649495EB3C7C9C6057AA50B.description:
The body has acute and possible long-term responses to the environment in which it
functions.

42B9AA9250854B2FAEA1F4CF5A14C97F.description:
Homeostasis is any self-regulating biological process aiming to produce a relatively stable,
constant internal environment for optimal functioning of the body. In response to changing
internal and external conditions, various mechanisms work constantly towards homeostasis.

6DD2AD6CF82049E1B38CAF891917D8A5.description:
The endocrine system, made up of the body's glands and hormones, regulates all
biological processes in the body.

550DE9B1015C4E248665BACF9C4E9A10.description:
The nervous system senses both internal and external conditions to coordinate the
responses of the body’s physiological systems effectively.

41C81E537AC045DA8AA3A7DEEDF2B708.description:
Exercise physiology and nutrition of the human
body
